node.text: No, no, no! Nature is not your servant!
We must strive to coexist within it, in harmony - not to control it!

option.optiontext: Continue listening.

node.text: You argue out of emotion, bearded man. Simply, magic is control, of all things, even nature. Why should we then not use it?

option.optiontext: Continue listening.

node.text: You yourself employ magic, do you not? It seems to me we are merely arguing semantics here, about what kind of magic is appropriate.

option.optiontext: Continue listening.
Enough, this going nowhere!

node.text: It is astonishing how you devote your entire life to its study, yet you misunderstand magic entirely.

option.optiontext: Continue listening.
Enough, this going nowhere!

node.text: Magic is a language, a form of communication! My magic asks of nature, whereas yours demands from it. It will not tolerate such an insult for long and it's already showing signs of anguish!

option.optiontext: Continue listening.
Enough, this going nowhere!

node.text: So you say... You know, you druids do not reside everywhere, but I daresay wizardry almost does. Yet somehow in all the other lands magic hasn't brought about the end of the world. I think we'll be just fine here too.
And perhaps nature is not the same everywhere? Perhaps there is a reason we druids prefer certain places over others? Hm, what do you say, traveler? You seem awfully quiet.

option.optiontext: The world shouldn't revolve around the sensitivites of tired old tree beards. Magic solves far more problems than it creates.
Magic's useful, but we shouldn't rely on it to the point of disrupting nature. There is always another way.
I'm not really the right person to take sides in this, I'll leave you to it.

node.text: Another fool impressed by the shiny baubles the magi have to offer? How typical! One day you will regret those words, one day... but by then it will be too late.

Disappointing how you should be swayed by the scaremongering of this bearded man. Understand that he's a dated old creature, only afraid of his own dwindling relevance in the world - and that of his kind.
I take it you have an opinion on this matter, stranger?

option.optiontext: The world shouldn't revolve around the sensitivites of tired old tree beards. Magic solves far more problems than it creates.
Magic's useful, but we shouldn't rely on it to the point of disrupting nature. There is always another way.
I don't care one way or the other, just take your shouting elsewhere.

node.text: I am pleased to see not everyone has fallen victim to the arrogance of the Hydrobor Magi.

option.optiontext: I seek the Forest's Heart. Surely a mighty druid is the right person to ask?
How fares the forest?
Why is the presence of the magi so distressing?

node.text: A mighty druid, eh? Might is not among the things we seek, but peace and harmony. Well, it's not every day one is asked for an audience with the Forest's Heart.

I don't mean to doubt your intentions, but we druids prefer to exercise caution when it comes to the nature's artifacts. Perhaps an act of friendship towards the forest might pave your way to its heart, hm?

option.optiontext: How would I become a friend of the forest?
Hm... perhaps another time.

node.text: See this tree here? It is a young Imret Silver Oak. Remarkable, intelligent trees, though most are unaware of the fact. Its ancestor grows southeast of here. An older specimen that one, its bark has finally turned silver.

Take an offering to the old tree; bring with you ten unusual acorns and a handful of mistypine needles. Use the acorns to form a ring and spread the needles in its center, then bury the symbol by the old Silverbark's roots.
Should the tree accept your offering, it will give you a token in return - a silvery cone. Bring the cone to me and I shall then consecrate it.

option.optiontext: I see...

node.text: The Mistywood has always been nature's prime sanctuaries in these lands, but even here the disease men call ''civilization'' has begun to creep in.
Hydrobor magics, industrialists from the city of Haywind... loggers. Nature does not welcome them. But I wonder, would nature find a friend in you?

option.optiontext: What would nature ask of me?
Hm... perhaps another time.

node.text: The arrogant fools! They believe they can use their magics to twist nature's hand, to force it into their service! They've already altered the weather around Haywind to favor the farmers' crops, so the ignorant peasants rejoice. Meanwhile, nature groans in pain...

node.text: You feel a slight whoosh of the wind. Somewhere, one of the tree's branches shakes and a silvery old cone drops onto the ground. You pick it up in gratitude.

Oh good, the tree beard's finally gone. There are always those who'd fear and hate the magi. Usually it's superstitious peasants carrying torches and pitchforks, but why not bearded men living in treehouses also?

option.optiontext: Happen to know anything about this gem I found?
What are you doing all the way out here?

node.text: Studying magic. The druid was right about one thing, magic is different in these woods. Manipulating weather is relatively easy around Haywind, but here the air is far more resistant somehow.

option.optiontext: Happen to know anything about this gem I found?

node.text: Where did you find this? This is no ordinary gem - it's not a gem at all - it's a lightning stone! Incredibly rare, they only form in magical storms.

option.optiontext: That would make sense, is it worth anything?

node.text: To some, yes I'd say it's quite valuable. The lightning stone is highly in tune with the magic of the skies. If you bring me oak, I might be able to fashion it into a wand capable of manipulating its power.

option.optiontext: Very well, please craft this wand for me. <color=orange> (Strange Gem + 5 Oak) </color>

node.text: As you wish, traveler.\n\n<color=#9C8C77> *Using magic, it does not take long for Meara to bend the wood ornately into shape around the gem.* </color>
Your wand, traveler - may it grant the fury of the skies to your service. And I personally wouldn't mind if you fried a druid or two with it.

option.optiontext: I'm sure it will come in handy, thank you.
